title: More than 500 species infected, 300 billion birds dead due to avian flu H5N1: WHO - Down To Earth Magazine
summary:
Over 500 Species Infected and 300 Billion Birds Dead from H5N1: WHO Warns

Date: 18 Dec 2024

Source: World Health Organization

The Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) H5N1 has infected over 500 species and led to over 300 billion bird deaths globally. The UN has reported that the virus poses significant risks to both wildlife and human livelihoods, particularly in poultry-dependent regions.

  • HPAI H5N1 has spread to 108 countries and has infected numerous wildlife species.
  • The virus poses a threat to food security and livelihoods, especially for poultry farmers.
  • Seventy-six human cases of H5N1 have been reported in 2024, primarily among farm workers.
  • The WHO urges increased surveillance and preventive measures regarding the virus.
“There is no evidence so far that the H5N1 viruses have adapted to spread between people,” said Maria Van Kerkhove, WHO.

This situation highlights the need for a multi-sectoral approach to address avian influenza's spread.
newTitle: Over 500 Species Infected and 300 Billion Birds Dead from H5N1: WHO Warns

Russia Develops New MRNA Cancer Vaccine, Set For Free Distribution By 2025 - Zee News
summary:
Russia Develops New MRNA Cancer Vaccine, Set For Free Distribution By 2025

Publication Date: N/A Source: TASS

In a significant advancement, Russia has developed an mRNA-based vaccine targeting cancer, which is slated to be available to patients at no cost by 2025.

Collaborative Effort and Development

Andrey Kaprin, General Director of the Radiology Medical Research Centre, confirmed that the vaccine was developed in collaboration with various research institutions.

Promising Pre-Clinical Results

Pre-clinical trials have shown the vaccine's effectiveness in suppressing tumor growth and preventing metastases. Kaprin stated, “The vaccine’s pre-clinical trials have shown that it effectively suppresses tumor development and potential metastases.”

Presidential Endorsement

Vladimir Putin emphasized the progress in cancer research, hoping for the effective use of these vaccines in individual therapy.

How the mRNA Vaccine Targets Cancer

The mRNA vaccine instructs the body’s cells to produce a protein associated with cancer cells, training the immune system to target and eliminate the disease.

Future Prospects

This mRNA cancer vaccine marks a pivotal moment in medical research, aiming for a 2025 release that could transform cancer treatment.
newTitle: Russia Develops New MRNA Cancer Vaccine, Set For Free Distribution By 2025

title: Dinga Dinga: Mysterious 'dancing' disease that Ugandans are suffering - DNA India
summary:
Dinga Dinga: Mysterious 'Dancing' Disease Affecting Ugandans

Publication Date: December 18, 2024 Source: DNA India

A new disease known as Dinga Dinga is rapidly spreading in Uganda's Bundibugyo district, causing uncontrollable shaking in affected individuals, resembling dancing. Health officials are investigating its source and potential treatments.

  • The disease primarily affects women and children in Bundibugyo district.
  • Symptoms include unrestrained body shaking, excessive weakness, fever, and paralysis sensations.
  • Dr. Kiyita Christopher assures a high recovery rate with proper treatment using antibiotics.
  • Local campaigns are ongoing to discourage the use of unverified herbal medicines.
  • Research into the cause is underway, with health samples sent to the Ministry of Health.
"No one has been reported dead from the disease, and the health officials feel the disease can be cured with antibiotics."

The outbreak of Dinga Dinga presents a pressing public health challenge in Uganda, prompting urgent investigations and local health campaigns to inform and protect the community.
newTitle: Dinga Dinga: Mysterious 'Dancing' Disease Affecting Ugandans

title: Health benefits of drinking water: Can drinking more water be healthy? Perhaps - Moneycontrol
What is 'Dinga Dinga', dancing disease making Uganda people sick - NewsBytes
summary:
What is 'Dinga Dinga'—mystery body shaking disease spreading in Uganda

Publication Date: (Not Provided) Source: NewsBytes

A mysterious disease called "Dinga Dinga," which translates to "shaking like dancing," has emerged in Uganda, affecting mostly women and children.

  • The disease was first detected in the Bundibugyo district in early 2023.
  • About 300 people have shown symptoms, including excessive body shaking, high fever, and extreme weakness.
  • Patients have reported harrowing experiences, with most recovering within a week with antibiotics.
  • Public health campaigns are underway to educate residents and discourage unverified treatments.
  • A neighboring illness in the Democratic Republic of Congo has resulted in at least 79 deaths amidst 406 reported cases.
“I felt weak and got paralyzed, with my body shaking uncontrollably whenever I tried to walk.” - Patience Katusiime, 18

This unfolding situation highlights the need for ongoing health investigations and public awareness efforts to manage emerging health threats in the region.
newTitle: What is 'Dinga Dinga'—mystery body shaking disease spreading in Uganda

title: Living longer but not healthier: Study finds this country has biggest gap between lifespan and 'healthspan' - Hindustan Times
summary:
Living Longer but Not Healthier: Study Finds This Country Has Biggest Gap Between Lifespan and 'Healthspan'

Date: Dec 18, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

New research shows that while humans are living longer, this does not equate to living healthier lives. The study, which analyzed data from 183 countries, highlights a widening gap between lifespan and healthspan, with the US having the largest gap.

  • The average American will live 12.4 years with disability or illness.
  • Globally, lifespan increased from 79.2 to 80.7 years for women and from 74.1 to 76.3 years for men between 2000 and 2019.
  • The gap between lifespan and healthspan increased to an average of 9.6 years, a 13% rise since 2000.
  • The US has the greatest gap, reporting chronic disease as a significant issue due to mental health and substance abuse.
“The data show that gains in longevity are not matched with equivalent advances in healthy longevity” - Dr. Andre Terzic

This study emphasizes the necessity of addressing the healthspan-lifespan gap to improve the quality of life in older age.
newTitle: Living Longer but Not Healthier: Study Reveals Gap Between Lifespan and Healthspan

India sets up its first diabetes biobank in Chennai: Know its importance and why it matters - India TV News
summary:
India Establishes First Diabetes Biobank in Chennai

Published on: December 12, 2024 Source: India TV News

The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) and Madras Diabetes Research Foundation (MDRF) have created the country's first diabetes biobank in Chennai to facilitate research and improve treatment for diabetes, a growing health concern.

  • The biobank aims to conduct high-tech research to identify causes of diabetes.
  • It will help recognize diabetes at an early stage and discover new biomarkers for treatment.
  • The initiative will position India as a key player in the global fight against diabetes.
  • The first study of the biobank involved over 1.2 lakh individuals and highlighted the diabetes epidemic affecting over 10 crore people in India.
  • Type 1 and type 2 diabetes have been found increasingly prevalent among the youth, necessitating the biobank's contributions.
“The biobank will help in identifying diabetes at an early stage and identifying new biomarkers to improve treatment.” - Dr. V Mohan, MDRF President

The establishment of the diabetes biobank in Chennai marks a significant step towards combating diabetes in India and could lead to breakthroughs in treatment and management of the disease.
newTitle: India Establishes First Diabetes Biobank in Chennai

Can Tight Briefs Hurt Your Shot At Fatherhood? How 5 Lifestyle Choices Affect Male Fertility - ABP Live
summary:
Can Tight Underwear Hurt Your Shot At Fatherhood? 5 Lifestyle Choices & How They Affect Male Fertility

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: ABP Live

Male fertility is as crucial as female fertility in the journey to parenthood. This article discusses how various lifestyle choices can affect sperm health and overall male fertility.

  • Global studies indicate a significant decline in male fertility, with a 50-60% decrease in sperm counts from 1973 to 2011.
  • Hot or cold showers may impact sperm motility; moderate temperatures are recommended.
  • Excessive alcohol and tobacco consumption are harmful to sperm quality.
  • Tight underwear may not significantly harm fertility, but loose-fitting options are generally preferred.
  • Prolonged cycling over five hours a week is linked to lower sperm counts.
  • Keeping laptops on laps can increase scrotal temperature, potentially harming sperm health.
“For better sperm health, it’s often advised to wear loose-fitting underwear like boxers.” - Dr. Phani Madhuri

By adopting healthier lifestyle habits and avoiding detrimental ones, men can enhance their fertility and sperm health.
newTitle: Impact of Lifestyle Choices on Male Fertility: Key Insights

5 Easy ways vegetarians can boost vitamin D intake - India.com
summary:
5 Easy Ways Vegetarians Can Boost Vitamin D Intake

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: India.com

Vitamin D is crucial for maintaining strong bones, a healthy immune system, and proper muscle function.

  • Spending 15-20 minutes outdoors in the morning sunlight helps the body produce vitamin D naturally.
  • Cow's milk is naturally rich in vitamin D and is often fortified.
  • Cheese varieties like ricotta, cheddar, or Swiss contain small amounts of vitamin D.
  • Certain mushrooms, like maitake and shiitake, naturally contain vitamin D when exposed to sunlight.
  • Fortified tofu and soy products often contain added vitamin D.
Excessive vitamin D intake can lead to kidney damage, nausea, and calcium buildup in the blood.

By incorporating these foods and practices, vegetarians can effectively boost their vitamin D intake while being mindful of excessive consumption.
newTitle: 5 Easy Ways Vegetarians Can Boost Vitamin D Intake

title: The truth behind popular health foods: What you need to know - The Indian Express
summary:
The Truth Behind Popular Health Foods: What You Need to Know

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: The Indian Express

This article explores the misconceptions surrounding popular health foods and their actual nutritional benefits, emphasizing moderation and informed choices.

  • Foods labeled as "diet" or "low-calorie" can still have high calorie content.
  • Dark chocolate has health benefits but should be consumed in moderation.
  • Grilling lean meats can create harmful substances; it's healthier to consume them in soups.
  • Homemade curd is a better choice than low-fat yoghurts that may contain added sugars.
  • Artificial sweeteners can cause digestive issues and may be harmful if overconsumed.
  • A balanced diet should emphasize variety and moderation.
“A healthy diet relies on moderation, and a range of food options is necessary to satisfy nutritional requirements.”

In conclusion, understanding the true nutritional value of popular health foods is essential to making healthier dietary choices.
newTitle: The Truth Behind Popular Health Foods: What You Need to Know
